summary: He looked south, and saw the great blue-green rush of the Trident. He saw his father pleading with the king, his face etched...
text: He looked south, and saw the great blue-green rush of the Trident. He saw his father pleading with the king, his face etched with grief. He saw Sansa crying herself to sleep at night, and he saw Arya watching in silence and holding her secrets hard in her heart. There were shadows all around them. One shadow was dark as ash, with the terrible face of a hound. Another was armored like the sun, golden and beautiful. Over them both loomed a giant in armor made of stone, but when he opened his visor, there was nothing inside but darkness and thick black blood.
source:
A Game of Thrones, Bran III

This is part of the visions that Bran has when he’s unconscious after his fall from the Broken Tower. The first part of the vision seems to relate to the events of the Trident that resulted in Lady’s death.

The three shadows surrounding Sansa and Arya are very interesting to me. 

The first shadow with the “terrible face of a hound” most likely refers to Sandor Clegane, called the Hound and whose burned face is indeed terrible to behold.

The second shadow, “armored like the sun, golden and beautiful” could refer to Jaime Lannister who on occasion wears a golden suit of armor decorated with the heraldic lion of the Lannisters. However, there are no lions in this vision but rather a symbolic connection between the gold and the sun.

The third shadow is rather interesting: “a giant made of stone” but with no face beneath his visor, only darkness and black blood. This description seems to hint at the mysterious Kingsguard Ser Robert Strong, who most likely is the zombified remains of Ser Gregor Clegane, the Mountain that Rides.

Sandor Clegane has already played a part in both Sansa’s and Arya’s stories. Jaime Lannister is indirectly playing a role in their stories as well since he tasks Brienne with finding Catelyn Stark’s daughters to keep them safe.

The Mountain/Ser Gregor/Ser Robert has played a part in Arya’s story when she was at Harrenhal but he has yet to play a part in Sansa’s story.

summary: Have we considered that Bran might know about what’s happened with Jon’s stabbing (somebody’s been warging the ravens and would...
body:
Have we considered that Bran might know about what’s happened with Jon’s stabbing (somebody’s been warging the ravens and would bloodraven not tell him…?) and that may be part of the reason he needs Theon to go to the heart tree? Like ‘oh hi Theon, could you tell Stannis that Jon’s been murdered and he needs to get his army back to the Wall? And to stop burning my trees please? K thx bye’ Or maybe that’ll be part of Bran’s dark TWOW motivations, if he knows/saw his brother get murdered…

Actually, brain blanking, does Bran know what happened to Robb and Cat at the twins? At the very least Summer presumably sensed Grey Wind’s death and the Stark kids had dreams about their dad dying when that happened… I need to get back to my re-re-re-reread.

title: Trees of Ice and Fire
body:
This isn’t a meta per se but merely something I noticed years ago but I thought I’d bring it up again for those who might not have noticed these peculiar similarities. 

The first parallel is from Dany and Bran (who share many similarities when it comes to the magical aspect of the story). Below is the descriptions of what Shades of the Evening (the blue drink Dany is given before entering the HOTu and what Euron drinks) tastes like vs. what Weirwood paste taste like (the red drink given to Bran by the Children of the Forest).

Shades of the Evening & Weirwood Paste

“Dany raised the glass to her lips. The first sip tasted like ink and spoiled meat, foul, but when she swallowed, it seemed to come to life within her. She could feel tendrils spreading through her chest, like fingers of fire coiling around her heart, and on her tongue the taste was like honey and anise and cream, like mother’s milk and Drogo’s seed, like red meat and hot blood and molten gold. It was like all the tastes she had ever known, and none of them … and then the glass was empty.”

“It had a bitter taste, though not so bitter as the acorn paste. The first spoonful was the hardest to get down. He almost retched it right back up. The second tasted better. The third was almost sweet. The rest he spooned up eagerly. Why had he thought that it was bitter? It tasted of honey, of new-fallen snow, of pepper and cinnamon and the last kiss his mother gave him. The empty bowl slipped from his fingers and clattered on the floor.”

The descriptions of what these drinks taste like are extremely similar. What at first tasted bitter and spoiled becomes rich and sweet enough to taste like honey. Both of these substances are meant to allow both Dany and Bran to expand their senses in order to understand what they are about to see and experience.

The trees from where Shades of the Evening comes from have a black bark to them. I think that they must be a type of ebony tree. In the series, ebony seems to have some magical properties.

Ebony and Weirwood

“To her right , a set of wide wooden doors had been thrown open. They were fashioned of ebony and weirwood, the black and white grains swirling and twisting in strange interwoven patterns. They were very beautiful, yet somehow frightening.”

The is the second time we’ve encountered the combination of ebony and weirwood in doors, the first time was in the home of Tobbo Mott the blacksmith:

“The double doors showed a hunting scene carved in ebony and weirwood. A pair of stone knights stood sentry at the entrance, armored in fanciful suits of polished red steel that transformed them into griffin and unicorn.”

The third time in in the House of Black and White:

“At the top she found a set of carved wooden doors twelve feet high. The left-hand door was made of weirwood pale as bone, the right of gleaming ebony. In their center was a carved moon face; ebony on the weirwood side, weirwood on the ebony. The look of it reminded her somehow of the heart tree in the godswood at Winterfell.”

An interesting combination, it makes me wonder what kind of magical properties are brought together by combining these two kinds of wood.  Later in the series will see Dany seated in an ebony bench which she uses as a throne, her magical counterpart Bran will later sit in a weirwood “throne” inside the cave.

A pet theory of mine or more like a dream of mine would be to have the Iron Throne to be destroyed and to have a bench of weirwood and ebony for Jon and Dany to sit on as their joint throne.

I like the combination of the two woods, not only because of the connection to magic but also because there an “east / west” tied to them as well as the clear yin yang symbolism the two together evoke.

title:
BRAN’S VISION CLUSTER  #1
GoT S04E02
body:
In ‘The Lion and the Rose’, Bran stops at a weirwood Heart Tree beyond the Wall and he has his first vision cluster (the video for the whole thing can be watched here). While this vision cluster should be seen as a whole, as it actually metaphorically shows the same thing as the other prophetic vision Bran has later. The first two major subsets are the most developed, with the other two major subsets just a hint for what’s to come, as those will be expanded through other visions Bran will have.

This cluster vision is a set of eighteen distinct video clips, with about half of them being repurposed from past scenes (though there are a few new ones). This can be divided into four mutually exclusive subsets, as they are punctuated by an audio-visual cue: a black fade-out and a white flash-in, followed by a drum-like sound effect (this audio-visual cue is used recurrently from that point forward when Bran trips out). These divisions actually neatly list what things Bran is going to be looking at each season from this point forth.

NOTE: I attach a few observations with # before them at the end of each section, these are just speculation based on things and not really part of this exercise.

………………………………………… subtle

FIRST VISION : hero journey

The first vision is composed of four clips, detailing Bran’s hero journey in season 4 (Bran didn’t feature in season 5, he was just “training”, so it doesn’t matter I know, urgh). This one is the easiest to understand in its full implications, since most of it has come to pass already and they’re the most straightforward.

The first two clips show where Bran must go, the Three-Eyed Raven Cave. The first clip is a weirwood Heart Tree over a cave entrance, which is how the place proper is depicted, and the second clip is a myriad of roots crisscrossing, typical of the inside layout of said cave. These two are very upfront, the real deal looks exactly like that after all.

The third clip shows who Bran will meet and who he will become, the Three-Eyed Raven. The show introduces the novel concept that the Three-Eyed Raven is both Brynden Rivers and Bran Stark (chalking up any ???? as “difficult to explain” also known as, this is never getting explained in the show, forget about it). Obviously, neither of them is a raven with three eyes, but that’s their symbolic figure which everyone associates with these two characters anyway (#A).

The fourth clip show what Bran will learn at the cave, to look into the past. There’s a close-up to the raven’s claw taking impulse and taking off, a reference to the jumping and flying motif that Bran has (more apparent in the books, but the show kept Brynden saying “you’ll never walk again, but you will fly”). Then, the raven flying down the Winterfell Crypts, metaphorical travelling through time as that’s a funerary crypt, representative of the past. As a side-note, the fact that these are the Winterfell Crypts, where all Starks are buried, is suggestive that the past that he’s going to be looking into is tied to House Stark.

#A: Rivers is identified as the Three-Eyed Crow, though he has raven messengers instead. Unless this is a case of the show changing book concepts because the dumb general audience might get confused (Asha being renamed Yara, so she won’t be confounded with Osha), then this suggests that a mashup streamlining took place somewhere.

In the books, this suggests that Bran’s final form is the Three-Eyed Raven, because he’s the important character in the narrative, as well as Bran surpassing Rivers as a greenseer, since ravens are portrayed as superior to crows. Furthermore, it  suggests that Rivers will die in the cave while Bran will go back to Winterfell, since “crows” (Brothers of the Night’s Watch) are bound to the Wall for life (the roots of the Three-Eyed Cave are shackles for Rivers as well) while ravens (messenger ravens) are taken to other places inside cages (Bran too is bound as a cripple and has to be taken somewhere by others) but will fly home when released. Moreover, it suggests that the abnormal talking raven at the Wall has something to do with this streamlining, since he has been linked to Rivers before (at least once, in Jon I ~ ADWD), yet he was cut entirely from the show (and only an idiot wouldn’t add a talking bird, which has huge potential in turning into a mascot and sell ridiculous amounts of merchandise, unless the gains were bigger than the losses)

SECOND VISION : past

The second vision is composed of nine clips, detailing what Bran is going to be looking at in season 6. This one can be divided into two major groups, one centred in Ned and one centred in the White Walkers, for the sake of simplification that is what I did. They’re actually pretty extra and pretty stupid if taken at first value (and this episode was written by GRRM, so that’s unlikely), so they beg the viewer to put their tinfoil hat on and analyse the epileptic trees, so I did.

EDDARD STARK

The first two clips show Eddard Stark and his role in R+L=J, roughly corresponding to Bran’s three flashbacks about his father’s past which all feature Lyanna. Though separated by the audio-visual cue, these clips follow the raven flying down the Winterfell Crypts, which highly suggested that the visions that would follow would be about House Stark, specifically of people that were buried there. Accordingly, these two clips are about Ned as well as Lyanna, which are both Starks buried at the Winterfell Crypts.

The fifth clip is Ned sharpening Ice, an allegory for Ned’s going to war for the sake of his sister. To sharpen a sword is to prepare it for battle and adding this scene specifically is especially glaring because Ice is a Valyrian steel sword which doesn’t need to be sharpened in the first place (they also bothered to film a new scene instead of repurposing the clip where Ned cleans Ice with an oilcloth from the very first episode - even their hands are switched - because that thematic wouldn’t fit). It corresponds to Bran’s Winterfell flasback in ‘Home’, where Ned is sparring with Benjen (training for battle) and Lyanna shows up to hang out for a bit (highlighting the bond between the siblings), as well as Bran’s first Tower of Joy flashback in ‘Oathbreaker’, where Ned fights against the Kingsguard with the objective of rescuing Lyanna (B1) .

The sixth clip feature Ned while he’s imprisoned at the Black Cells in King’s Landing, the fire bursting to life in the background and reflected in his eyes (#B2); an allegory of Ned witnessing Jon’s birth (he is half a fire child after all, I know, urgh, poor boy) and his promise to Lyanna which has held him “captive” for half of his life (this binding motif is more obvious in the books, as Ned thinks about Lyanna and this promise frequently). It corresponds to Bran’s flashback in ‘The Winds of Winter’, where Ned goes up the staircase as Lyanna is screaming from giving birth (her dress is also bloody, which means she just did it, otherwise she would’ve been cleaned by whatever attendant there) as well as Lyanna asking Ned to protect the new-born Jon.

#B1: I was told that the original script for this would be more extensive, including a scene with Bran’s uncle Benjen and Lyanna Stark as children, so one more notch on the bedpost.

#B2: There’s some eye thing going here. The fire is reflected in Ned’s eyes, the correspondent scene has a focus on Jon’s eyes both as a baby and as an adult (even in the scripts). It’s worth noting that in the show, they changed Jon’s eye-colour from grey (like Ned’s) to brown (and cast Lyanna with brown eyes). There might be something dumb about eye-colour in season 8.

WHITE WALKERS

The following four clips show stuff from Beyond the Wall, corresponding to Bran’s flashbacks about the Night King / White Walkers / Wights. These are presented differently from the ones with Ned, because they need to establish a time context which wasn’t needed with him (we knew when he lived). They do so through the visual cue of the sun travelling through the sky in the background of the weirwood Heart Three over the Three-Eyed Cave (like the “time machine” that they’re “travelling” on). This tree motif is repeated in subsequent visions for the same reasons.

The seventh clip is a frozen wasteland, with really busy clouds in the sky and the sunrise with the sun hanging really low while it goes from “right to left”, which is an allegory for time going back in the “true north” during winter (a very good one). It follows with the Three-Eyed Cave entrance with the sun on the very far left after having travelled from “right to left”, which is an allegory for having reached the “very beginning” of something (a very bad one, as a physics major this offends me). In other words, Bran is going to look very far into the past for what comes next (B2).

The eight clip is a raven landing on a branch followed by the face of a weirwood Heart Tree and the tenth clip is the myriad of roots crisscrossing once again, which shows how they’re going to do what’s in the aforementioned paragraph, the Three-Eyed Raven(s) are going to use the Weirwood Network (#C). Sandwiched between them, the ninth clip is the very first wight we see properly in this series in ‘Winter is Coming’ (and a murder of ravens flying through the forest), which establishes what they’re going to be looking at the “very beginning”, the origins of the Night King / White Walkers / Wights. It corresponds to Bran’s flashback seeing the creation of the Night King in ‘The Door’ (B3).

#B2: The eight and tenth clip aren’t redundant as it may seem on first approach. At the time those visions were shown, the audience “doesn’t know” how these visions are being accessed (yes, Bran touched the tree, but nothing else… and the show audience should be “flying blind” without the book information). It also suggests that while all visions are being accessed through the Weirwood Network, the ones for the Night King’s visions were accessible because they are “recorded” within the network (the raven touches the tree), Ned’s visions were accessible due to being buried in the Winterfell Crypts which the Winterfell’s weirwood Heart Tree most likely is connected to (the raven goes through the Winterfell Crypts).

#B3: Bran returns here shortly after and there is this gesture, which may either be a signal that the pact was broken by men and / or that the Night King seeks the pact once again.

THIRD VISION : present

The third vision is composed of three clips, the first sets timing which is the present and the other two set the focus subjects, which also detail how Bran uses his powers in season 7. He actually wasn’t shown using his powers much in season 7 on-screen (most of what he did was off-screen), but when he did use them on-screen, it was to understand these two present predicaments.

The eleventh clip is the Three-Eyed Cave entrance with the sun travelling from “left to right” and stopping behind it (right in the centre of the screen), which signals time is going to the present once again. In other words, Bran is going to look through the Weirwood Network because of present predicaments.

The twelfth clip is a wight horse, symbolical of the Night King / White Walkers / Wight marching south to invade Westeros. The horse imagery alone is representative of movement and it could’ve actually stop there, but the whole scene of ‘Valar Morghulis’ from where it was repurposed from shows the army of White Walkers / Wights marching south which reinforces this point even further. It corresponds to Bran checking out the army of Night King / White Walkers / Wights progress in ‘Dragonstone’ and ‘Eastwatch’.

The thirteenth clip is a very long shot of the Iron Throne covered in snow, allegorical of Jon as the true heir to the Iron Throne. This scene is similar to Danielle’s vision in the House of the Undying in ‘Valar Morghulis’, but it’s actually a new scene which deliberately excludes Danielle’s presence. For the sake of production, the graphic montages for both were probably produced at the same time and they mean the exact same thing: Jon Snow is the legitimate and undisputable heir to the Iron Throne, Danielle has no part in it whatsoever. It corresponds to Bran checking out Jon’s true heritage as heir to the Iron Throne in ‘The Dragon and the Wolf’.

FOURTH VISION : future

The fourth vision is composed of six clips, detailing the two wars to come in season 8 and for those, Bran will be instrumental: the one against Night King / Others and the one against Danielle / Dragons. This is ‘The Song of Ice and Fire’.

The fourteenth clip is the Night King seen through the broken ice, which is symbolical of the struggle against the destructive force of ice (I don’t recognise the inspiration for this, but some horror movie maybe). The sixteenth clip is a dragon flying over King’s Landing, which is symbolical of the struggle against the destructive force of fire (now this… I recognise the inspiration for this 🛩️). ‘Some say the world will end in fire, some say in ice… *blah blah*’ These conflicts are both expanded upon in a subsequent Bran vision in ‘Blood of my Blood’.

The fifteenth clip is a raven flying and Bran falling down the Broken Tower, with the seventeenth clip continuing the aforementioned fall. On one hand and visually, Bran falling down the Broken Tower is put between the fourteenth and sixteenth clip and eighteenth clip. On the other hand and audibly, Cersei’s voice saying ‘he saw us’ is superimposed with the fourteenth and Bran’s screaming (this is not his original scream as a child in that scene, it was something they added specifically for this cluster vision and it’s his voice as a teenager) leaks into the screaming dragon.

These two clips reference back to Jaime throwing Bran out of the window, after the kid saw him having sex with Cersei, as well as the near death-experience that allowed him to become the Three-Eyed Raven. All of this suggests that Jaime may have a major role to play in the conflict (interestingly, he features a LOT in that subsequent Bran vision in ‘Blood of my Blood’), but most importantly that Bran and his greenseer powers will be instrumental in these two wars (D1).

The eighteenth clip is the Three-Eyed Cave entrance with the sun travelling from “left to right” from the centre to the right (towards the “end” of the screen), which is an allegory for time going into the future. It’s worth noting that this doesn’t come at the beginning of each subset, after the audio-visual cue, but right at the very end of everything (D2).

D1: The audio cues are intriguing. The first suggests that Bran ‘seeing’ will resolve the conflict with the Night King / White Walkers / Wights and we know that in his case, ‘seeing’ also means looking into the past and learning things that resolve the present. The second suggests that Bran ‘screaming’ will resolve the conflict with Danielle / dragons, which sounds dumb until you realise the sound of Bran ‘screaming’ leaks into the sound of dragon’s ‘screeching’ and we know that in his case, a human-animal transition also means skinchanging (and “you’ll never walk again, but you will fly” as well as Bran’s wish to be a knight and he can be a dragonknight ✨).

D2: This shtick of the sun travelling from “left to right” is the equivalent of a day, with the sunrise at the left and the sunset at the right. In this vision cluster, the sunrise was used to lynchpin the origins of Night King / White Walkers / Wights and which is also known as The War for the Dawn, while the sunset comes after everything, The “day” started after a Long Night and as such, this suggests that another Long Night is coming again at the end of Game of Thrones.
body_abstract:
In ‘The Lion and the Rose’, Bran stops at a weirwood Heart Tree beyond the Wall and he has his first vision cluster (the video for the whole thing can be watched here). While this vision cluster should be seen as a whole, as it actually metaphorically shows the same thing as the other prophetic vision Bran has later. The first two major subsets are the most developed, with the other two major subsets just a hint for what’s to come, as those will be expanded through other visions Bran will have.

This cluster vision is a set of eighteen distinct video clips, with about half of them being repurposed from past scenes (though there are a few new ones). This can be divided into four mutually exclusive subsets, as they are punctuated by an audio-visual cue: a black fade-out and a white flash-in, followed by a drum-like sound effect (this audio-visual cue is used recurrently from that point forward when Bran trips out). These divisions actually neatly list what things Bran is going to be looking at each season from this point forth.

NOTE: I attach a few observations with # before them at the end of each section, these are just speculation based on things and not really part of this exercise.

………………………………………… subtle

The first vision is composed of four clips, detailing Bran’s hero journey in season 4 (Bran didn’t feature in season 5, he was just “training”, so it doesn’t matter I know, urgh). This one is the easiest to understand in its full implications, since most of it has come to pass already and they’re the most straightforward.

The first two clips show where Bran must go, the Three-Eyed Raven Cave. The first clip is a weirwood Heart Tree over a cave entrance, which is how the place proper is depicted, and the second clip is a myriad of roots crisscrossing, typical of the inside layout of said cave. These two are very upfront, the real deal looks exactly like that after all.

The third clip shows who Bran will meet and who he will become, the Three-Eyed Raven. The show introduces the novel concept that the Three-Eyed Raven is both Brynden Rivers and Bran Stark (chalking up any ???? as “difficult to explain” also known as, this is never getting explained in the show, forget about it). Obviously, neither of them is a raven with three eyes, but that’s their symbolic figure which everyone associates with these two characters anyway (#A).

The fourth clip show what Bran will learn at the cave, to look into the past. There’s a close-up to the raven’s claw taking impulse and taking off, a reference to the jumping and flying motif that Bran has (more apparent in the books, but the show kept Brynden saying “you’ll never walk again, but you will fly”). Then, the raven flying down the Winterfell Crypts, metaphorical travelling through time as that’s a funerary crypt, representative of the past. As a side-note, the fact that these are the Winterfell Crypts, where all Starks are buried, is suggestive that the past that he’s going to be looking into is tied to House Stark.

#A: Rivers is identified as the Three-Eyed Crow, though he has raven messengers instead. Unless this is a case of the show changing book concepts because the dumb general audience might get confused (Asha being renamed Yara, so she won’t be confounded with Osha), then this suggests that a mashup streamlining took place somewhere.

In the books, this suggests that Bran’s final form is the Three-Eyed Raven, because he’s the important character in the narrative, as well as Bran surpassing Rivers as a greenseer, since ravens are portrayed as superior to crows. Furthermore, it  suggests that Rivers will die in the cave while Bran will go back to Winterfell, since “crows” (Brothers of the Night’s Watch) are bound to the Wall for life (the roots of the Three-Eyed Cave are shackles for Rivers as well) while ravens (messenger ravens) are taken to other places inside cages (Bran too is bound as a cripple and has to be taken somewhere by others) but will fly home when released. The sixth clip feature Ned while he’s imprisoned at the Black Cells in King’s Landing, the fire bursting to life in the background and reflected in his eyes (#B2); an allegory of Ned witnessing Jon’s birth (he is half a fire child after all, I know, urgh, poor boy) and his promise to Lyanna which has held him “captive” for half of his life (this binding motif is more obvious in the books, as Ned thinks about Lyanna and this promise frequently). It corresponds to Bran’s flashback in ‘The Winds of Winter’, where Ned goes up the staircase as Lyanna is screaming from giving birth (her dress is also bloody, which means she just did it, otherwise she would’ve been cleaned by whatever attendant there) as well as Lyanna asking Ned to protect the new-born Jon.

#B1: I was told that the original script for this would be more extensive, including a scene with Bran’s uncle Benjen and Lyanna Stark as children, so one more notch on the bedpost.

#B2: There’s some eye thing going here. The fire is reflected in Ned’s eyes, the correspondent scene has a focus on Jon’s eyes both as a baby and as an adult (even in the scripts). It’s worth noting that in the show, they changed Jon’s eye-colour from grey (like Ned’s) to brown (and cast Lyanna with brown eyes). There might be something dumb about eye-colour in season 8.

WHITE WALKERS

The following four clips show stuff from Beyond the Wall, corresponding to Bran’s flashbacks about the Night King / White Walkers / Wights. These are presented differently from the ones with Ned, because they need to establish a time context which wasn’t needed with him (we knew when he lived). They do so through the visual cue of the sun travelling through the sky in the background of the weirwood Heart Three over the Three-Eyed Cave (like the “time machine” that they’re “travelling” on). This tree motif is repeated in subsequent visions for the same reasons.

The seventh clip is a frozen wasteland, with really busy clouds in the sky and the sunrise with the sun hanging really low while it goes from “right to left”, which is an allegory for time going back in the “true north” during winter (a very good one). It follows with the Three-Eyed Cave entrance with the sun on the very far left after having travelled from “right to left”, which is an allegory for having reached the “very beginning” of something (a very bad one, as a physics major this offends me). In other words, Bran is going to look very far into the past for what comes next (B2).

The eight clip is a raven landing on a branch followed by the face of a weirwood Heart Tree and the tenth clip is the myriad of roots crisscrossing once again, which shows how they’re going to do what’s in the aforementioned paragraph, the Three-Eyed Raven(s) are going to use the Weirwood Network (#C). Sandwiched between them, the ninth clip is the very first wight we see properly in this series in ‘Winter is Coming’ (and a murder of ravens flying through the forest), which establishes what they’re going to be looking at the “very beginning”, the origins of the Night King / White Walkers / Wights. It corresponds to Bran’s flashback seeing the creation of the Night King in ‘The Door’ (B3).

#B2: The eight and tenth clip aren’t redundant as it may seem on first approach. At the time those visions were shown, the audience “doesn’t know” how these visions are being accessed (yes, Bran touched the tree, but nothing else… and the show audience should be “flying blind” without the book information). It also suggests that while all visions are being accessed through the Weirwood Network, the ones for the Night King’s visions were accessible because they are “recorded” within the network (the raven touches the tree), Ned’s visions were accessible due to being buried in the Winterfell Crypts which the Winterfell’s weirwood Heart Tree most likely is connected to (the raven goes through the Winterfell Crypts).

#B3: Bran returns here shortly after and there is this gesture, which may either be a signal that the pact was broken by men and / or that the Night King seeks the pact once again.

THIRD VISION : present

The third vision is composed of three clips, the first sets timing which is the present and the other two set the focus subjects, which also detail how Bran uses his powers in season 7. He actually wasn’t shown using his powers much in season 7 on-screen (most of what he did was off-screen), but when he did use them on-screen, it was to understand these two present predicaments.

The eleventh clip is the Three-Eyed Cave entrance with the sun travelling from “left to right” and stopping behind it (right in the centre of the screen), which signals time is going to the present once again. In other words, Bran is going to look through the Weirwood Network because of present predicaments.

The twelfth clip is a wight horse, symbolical of the Night King / White Walkers / Wight marching south to invade Westeros. The horse imagery alone is representative of movement and it could’ve actually stop there, but the whole scene of ‘Valar Morghulis’ from where it was repurposed from shows the army of White Walkers / Wights marching south which reinforces this point even further. It corresponds to Bran checking out the army of Night King / White Walkers / Wights progress in ‘Dragonstone’ and ‘Eastwatch’.

The thirteenth clip is a very long shot of the Iron Throne covered in snow, allegorical of Jon as the true heir to the Iron Throne. This scene is similar to Danielle’s vision in the House of the Undying in ‘Valar Morghulis’, but it’s actually a new scene which deliberately excludes Danielle’s presence. For the sake of production, the graphic montages for both were probably produced at the same time and they mean the exact same thing: Jon Snow is the legitimate and undisputable heir to the Iron Throne, Danielle has no part in it whatsoever. It corresponds to Bran checking out Jon’s true heritage as heir to the Iron Throne in ‘The Dragon and the Wolf’.

FOURTH VISION : future

The fourth vision is composed of six clips, detailing the two wars to come in season 8 and for those, Bran will be instrumental: the one against Night King / Others and the one against Danielle / Dragons. This is ‘The Song of Ice and Fire’.

The fourteenth clip is the Night King seen through the broken ice, which is symbolical of the struggle against the destructive force of ice (I don’t recognise the inspiration for this, but some horror movie maybe). The sixteenth clip is a dragon flying over King’s Landing, which is symbolical of the struggle against the destructive force of fire (now this… I recognise the inspiration for this 🛩️). ‘Some say the world will end in fire, some say in ice… *blah blah*’ These conflicts are both expanded upon in a subsequent Bran vision in ‘Blood of my Blood’.

The fifteenth clip is a raven flying and Bran falling down the Broken Tower, with the seventeenth clip continuing the aforementioned fall. On one hand and visually, Bran falling down the Broken Tower is put between the fourteenth and sixteenth clip and eighteenth clip. On the other hand and audibly, Cersei’s voice saying ‘he saw us’ is superimposed with the fourteenth and Bran’s screaming (this is not his original scream as a child in that scene, it was something they added specifically for this cluster vision and it’s his voice as a teenager) leaks into the screaming dragon.

These two clips reference back to Jaime throwing Bran out of the window, after the kid saw him having sex with Cersei, as well as the near death-experience that allowed him to become the Three-Eyed Raven. All of this suggests that Jaime may have a major role to play in the conflict (interestingly, he features a LOT in that subsequent Bran vision in ‘Blood of my Blood’), but most importantly that Bran and his greenseer powers will be instrumental in these two wars (D1).

The eighteenth clip is the Three-Eyed Cave entrance with the sun travelling from “left to right” from the centre to the right (towards the “end” of the screen), which is an allegory for time going into the future. It’s worth noting that this doesn’t come at the beginning of each subset, after the audio-visual cue, but right at the very end of everything (D2).

D1: The audio cues are intriguing. The first suggests that Bran ‘seeing’ will resolve the conflict with the Night King / White Walkers / Wights and we know that in his case, ‘seeing’ also means looking into the past and learning things that resolve the present. The second suggests that Bran ‘screaming’ will resolve the conflict with Danielle / dragons, which sounds dumb until you realise the sound of Bran ‘screaming’ leaks into the sound of dragon’s ‘screeching’ and we know that in his case, a human-animal transition also means skinchanging (and “you’ll never walk again, but you will fly” as well as Bran’s wish to be a knight and he can be a dragonknight ✨).

D2: This shtick of the sun travelling from “left to right” is the equivalent of a day, with the sunrise at the left and the sunset at the right. In this vision cluster, the sunrise was used to lynchpin the origins of Night King / White Walkers / Wights and which is also known as The War for the Dawn, while the sunset comes after everything, The “day” started after a Long Night and as such, this suggests that another Long Night is coming again at the end of Game of Thrones.
trail.content:
In ‘The Lion and the Rose’, Bran stops at a weirwood Heart Tree beyond the Wall and he has his first vision cluster (the video for the whole thing can be watched here). While this vision cluster should be seen as a whole, as it actually metaphorically shows the same thing as the other prophetic vision Bran has later. The first two major subsets are the most developed, with the other two major subsets just a hint for what’s to come, as those will be expanded through other visions Bran will have.

This cluster vision is a set of eighteen distinct video clips, with about half of them being repurposed from past scenes (though there are a few new ones). This can be divided into four mutually exclusive subsets, as they are punctuated by an audio-visual cue: a black fade-out and a white flash-in, followed by a drum-like sound effect (this audio-visual cue is used recurrently from that point forward when Bran trips out). These divisions actually neatly list what things Bran is going to be looking at each season from this point forth.

NOTE: I attach a few observations with # before them at the end of each section, these are just speculation based on things and not really part of this exercise.

………………………………………… subtle

FIRST VISION : hero journey

The first vision is composed of four clips, detailing Bran’s hero journey in season 4 (Bran didn’t feature in season 5, he was just “training”, so it doesn’t matter I know, urgh). This one is the easiest to understand in its full implications, since most of it has come to pass already and they’re the most straightforward.

The first two clips show where Bran must go, the Three-Eyed Raven Cave. The first clip is a weirwood Heart Tree over a cave entrance, which is how the place proper is depicted, and the second clip is a myriad of roots crisscrossing, typical of the inside layout of said cave. These two are very upfront, the real deal looks exactly like that after all.

The third clip shows who Bran will meet and who he will become, the Three-Eyed Raven. The show introduces the novel concept that the Three-Eyed Raven is both Brynden Rivers and Bran Stark (chalking up any ???? as “difficult to explain” also known as, this is never getting explained in the show, forget about it). Obviously, neither of them is a raven with three eyes, but that’s their symbolic figure which everyone associates with these two characters anyway (#A).

The fourth clip show what Bran will learn at the cave, to look into the past. There’s a close-up to the raven’s claw taking impulse and taking off, a reference to the jumping and flying motif that Bran has (more apparent in the books, but the show kept Brynden saying “you’ll never walk again, but you will fly”). Then, the raven flying down the Winterfell Crypts, metaphorical travelling through time as that’s a funerary crypt, representative of the past. As a side-note, the fact that these are the Winterfell Crypts, where all Starks are buried, is suggestive that the past that he’s going to be looking into is tied to House Stark.

#A: Rivers is identified as the Three-Eyed Crow, though he has raven messengers instead. Unless this is a case of the show changing book concepts because the dumb general audience might get confused (Asha being renamed Yara, so she won’t be confounded with Osha), then this suggests that a mashup streamlining took place somewhere.

In the books, this suggests that Bran’s final form is the Three-Eyed Raven, because he’s the important character in the narrative, as well as Bran surpassing Rivers as a greenseer, since ravens are portrayed as superior to crows. Furthermore, it  suggests that Rivers will die in the cave while Bran will go back to Winterfell, since “crows” (Brothers of the Night’s Watch) are bound to the Wall for life (the roots of the Three-Eyed Cave are shackles for Rivers as well) while ravens (messenger ravens) are taken to other places inside cages (Bran too is bound as a cripple and has to be taken somewhere by others) but will fly home when released. Moreover, it suggests that the abnormal talking raven at the Wall has something to do with this streamlining, since he has been linked to Rivers before (at least once, in Jon I ~ ADWD), yet he was cut entirely from the show (and only an idiot wouldn’t add a talking bird, which has huge potential in turning into a mascot and sell ridiculous amounts of merchandise, unless the gains were bigger than the losses)

SECOND VISION : past

The second vision is composed of nine clips, detailing what Bran is going to be looking at in season 6. This one can be divided into two major groups, one centred in Ned and one centred in the White Walkers, for the sake of simplification that is what I did.
